values.title: Make radial menu optional on scene

values.description:
This pull request makes it possible to embed a GZ3D simulation / log playback scene into another webpage. 

All files needed to embed GzWeb on another page are bundled into a single file `gz3d.full.iface.js`, which can be included on any site. This file does not bring UI elements, so downstream sites can interact with the simulation through their own UI using events.

### Background

GzWeb was originally designed to work as a complete website., and as such:

* Includes GUI elements, which use jQuery and AngularJS, and many classes on the code interact directly with these elements.
* Assumes the scene takes up the whole window.
* Assumes all content is served from the current URL: both static content and simulation updates coming through websockets.

### Changes

This pull request is being broken into smaller ones to facilitate review and decrease the chance of introducing bugs. The following pull requests are part of this one:

* ~~Pull request #147 : Unify emitters, decouple Iface and Gui~~
* ~~Pull request #150 : Scene custom size~~
* ~~Pull request #152 : Make radial menu optional on scene~~

Other changes contained in this PR:

* Generation of `gz3d.iface.full.js` and `gz3d.iface.full.min.js` when `npm run update` is run. These files are not being version controlled.
* Add a demo (see below)
* Move `isTouchDevice` to `gz.js` (from pull request #141)
* Fixes to the URLs of materials
* :warning: **controversial** :warning: : Changed a couple lines on `ColladaLoader.js` - we may want to pull an upstream version instead, which will require more changes.

### Demo

`examples/embedded_scene.html ` shows the intended use of the new files. To run the demo:

1. Launch `gzserver`
1. Launch gzweb backend with `npm start`
1. Open the demo on a browser : `firefox examples/embedded_scene.html`
1. Fill in the URL box with the GzWeb backend URL and press `Connect`
1. A scene will be created and connected to the simulation which is running on another server. The example also shows how to subscribe to information from the server (world stats) and to send requests to the server (play/pause):

![exampleembeddedplay.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/340720946-exampleembeddedplay.gif)
values.title: Embeddable GZ3D

All files needed to embed GzWeb on another page are bundled into a single file `gz3d.full.iface.js`, which can be included on any site. This file does not bring UI elements, so downstream sites can interact with the simulation through their own UI using events.

### Background

GzWeb was originally designed to work as a complete website., and as such:

* Includes GUI elements, which use jQuery and AngularJS, and many classes on the code interact directly with these elements.
* Assumes the scene takes up the whole window.
* Assumes all content is served from the current URL: both static content and simulation updates coming through websockets.

### Changes

This pull request is being broken into smaller ones to facilitate review and decrease the chance of introducing bugs. The following pull requests are part of this one:

### Demo

summary.html:
This pull request makes it possible to embed a GZ3D simulation / log playback scene into another webpage.

All files needed to embed GzWeb on another page are bundled into a single file gz3d.full.iface.js, which can be included on any site. This file does not bring UI elements, so downstream sites can interact with the simulation through their own UI using events.

Background

GzWeb was originally designed to work as a complete website., and as such:

  • Includes GUI elements, which use jQuery and AngularJS, and many classes on the code interact directly with these elements.
  • Assumes the scene takes up the whole window.
  • Assumes all content is served from the current URL: both static content and simulation updates coming through websockets.

Changes

This pull request is being broken into smaller ones to facilitate review and decrease the chance of introducing bugs. The following pull requests are part of this one:

  • Pull request #147 : Unify emitters, decouple Iface and Gui
  • Pull request #150 : Scene custom size
  • Pull request #152 : Make radial menu optional on scene

Other changes contained in this PR:

  • Generation of gz3d.iface.full.js and gz3d.iface.full.min.js when npm run update is run. These files are not being version controlled.
  • Add a demo (see below)
  • Move isTouchDevice to gz.js (from pull request #141)
  • Fixes to the URLs of materials
  • controversial : Changed a couple lines on ColladaLoader.js - we may want to pull an upstream version instead, which will require more changes.

Demo

examples/embedded_scene.html shows the intended use of the new files. To run the demo:

  1. Launch gzserver
  2. Launch gzweb backend with npm start
  3. Open the demo on a browser : firefox examples/embedded_scene.html
  4. Fill in the URL box with the GzWeb backend URL and press Connect
  5. A scene will be created and connected to the simulation which is running on another server. The example also shows how to subscribe to information from the server (world stats) and to send requests to the server (play/pause):

values.description:
Address issue #145

* Concatenated files:

    * gz3d.js =  (src - gui) + dependencies
    * gz3d.gui.js = src + dependencies
    * gz3d.src.js = src

* Minified versions are created for each of them
* No longer keep track of `gz3d/build/gz3d.js`. Instead, make sure it is generated during deploy by calling `grunt build`
* Use `gz3d.js` in the embedded example 
* Use `gz3d.gui.js` in the main `index.html`
* Use `gz3d.src.js` during tests. This is necessary because we need to control the order of dependency inclusions.
values.title: Naming scheme for concatenated files

* Minified versions are created for each of them
* No longer keep track of `gz3d/build/gz3d.js`. Instead, make sure it is generated during deploy by calling `grunt build`
* Use `gz3d.js` in the embedded example

* Use `gz3d.src.js` during tests. This is necessary because we need to control the order of dependency inclusions.
summary.html:
Address issue #145

  • Concatenated files:

    • gz3d.js = (src - gui) + dependencies
    • gz3d.gui.js = src + dependencies
    • gz3d.src.js = src

  • Minified versions are created for each of them

  • No longer keep track of gz3d/build/gz3d.js. Instead, make sure it is generated during deploy by calling grunt build
  • Use gz3d.js in the embedded example
  • Use gz3d.gui.js in the main index.html
  • Use gz3d.src.js during tests. This is necessary because we need to control the order of dependency inclusions.

values.description:
the canvas can't get focus so the dom element doesn't get key events. It used to be done with `document.addEventListener`

 I moved the keydown event binding to `index.html` instead of making it work inside gzscene.js in case other apps embedding gzweb don't want these events.
values.title: Fix keydown event

summary.raw:
the canvas can't get focus so the dom element doesn't get key events. It used to be done with `document.addEventListener`

 I moved the keydown event binding to `index.html` instead of making it work inside gzscene.js in case other apps embedding gzweb don't want these events.
summary.html:
the canvas can't get focus so the dom element doesn't get key events. It used to be done with document.addEventListener

I moved the keydown event binding to index.html instead of making it work inside gzscene.js in case other apps embedding gzweb don't want these events.

values.description:
updated based on this [post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/11580961/sending-command-line-arguments-to-npm-script)

pass args by adding `--` after run script, e.g.:

~~~
npm run deploy -- -m
~~~

~~~

values.title: Support publishing sdf string to ~/factory topic

values.description:
we have been using the `get_value` function in pb2json.cc for reading values of json field but that's inefficient and does not support arrays or checking optional fields. 

I added a simple JsonObj class so we only need to parse the json string once and then be able read different fields. Also added a `bool operator` so we can check if a field exists or not,  e.g. [this line](#!/osrf/gzweb/src/c7561c83a9b216002c5b2af2543253a8c6624b2e/gzbridge/GazeboInterface.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#GazeboInterface.cc-320) checks to see if the  `link` array field is present.

Currently only used when gzweb publishes a `~/model/modify` message to gzserver, which occurs when a user moves a model in gzweb.
values.title: Add JsonObj class for parsing and reading json values

summary.raw:
we have been using the `get_value` function in pb2json.cc for reading values of json field but that's inefficient and does not support arrays or checking optional fields. 

I added a simple JsonObj class so we only need to parse the json string once and then be able read different fields. Also added a `bool operator` so we can check if a field exists or not,  e.g. [this line](#!/osrf/gzweb/src/c7561c83a9b216002c5b2af2543253a8c6624b2e/gzbridge/GazeboInterface.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#GazeboInterface.cc-320) checks to see if the  `link` array field is present.

Currently only used when gzweb publishes a `~/model/modify` message to gzserver, which occurs when a user moves a model in gzweb.
summary.html:
we have been using the get_value function in pb2json.cc for reading values of json field but that's inefficient and does not support arrays or checking optional fields.

I added a simple JsonObj class so we only need to parse the json string once and then be able read different fields. Also added a bool operator so we can check if a field exists or not, e.g. this line checks to see if the link array field is present.

Currently only used when gzweb publishes a ~/model/modify message to gzserver, which occurs when a user moves a model in gzweb.

values.description:
The new `GZ3D.Ogre2Json` does on the browser what the `gzbridge`'s `OgreMaterialParser` and `ConfigLoader` do on the backend.

---

How it works:

1. It uses regex to convert an Ogre material script into JSON
1. Stores that JSON into `this.materialObj`
1. Collects specific material properties which are needed by `GZ3D.SdfParser`, following the same principle as `OgreMaterialParser`
1. Emits a `material` event with the materials (just like `gziface` does with the materials parsed using C++)

---

Other notes:

* The  example has been changed to make use of this, give it a try!
* Added dependency on lodash for more convenient handling of deep object properties
* Added the `npm run update-dev` command which concatenates files but doesn't lint or minify (convenient for developing)
* The tests should also give a good idea of how the new functions work
values.title: Client-side Ogre material parser

summary.raw:
The new `GZ3D.Ogre2Json` does on the browser what the `gzbridge`'s `OgreMaterialParser` and `ConfigLoader` do on the backend.

---

How it works:

1. It uses regex to convert an Ogre material script into JSON
1. Stores that JSON into `this.materialObj`
1. Collects specific material properties which are needed by `GZ3D.SdfParser`, following the same principle as `OgreMaterialParser`
1. Emits a `material` event with the materials (just like `gziface` does with the materials parsed using C++)

---

Other notes:

* The  example has been changed to make use of this, give it a try!
* Added dependency on lodash for more convenient handling of deep object properties
* Added the `npm run update-dev` command which concatenates files but doesn't lint or minify (convenient for developing)
* The tests should also give a good idea of how the new functions work
summary.html:
The new GZ3D.Ogre2Json does on the browser what the gzbridge's OgreMaterialParser and ConfigLoader do on the backend.

How it works:

  1. It uses regex to convert an Ogre material script into JSON
  2. Stores that JSON into this.materialObj
  3. Collects specific material properties which are needed by GZ3D.SdfParser, following the same principle as OgreMaterialParser
  4. Emits a material event with the materials (just like gziface does with the materials parsed using C++)

Other notes:

  • The example has been changed to make use of this, give it a try!
  • Added dependency on lodash for more convenient handling of deep object properties
  • Added the npm run update-dev command which concatenates files but doesn't lint or minify (convenient for developing)
  • The tests should also give a good idea of how the new functions work

values.description:
So far, visuals were filtered explicitly and only allowed a specific collision visual. Remove the filter and update the position.

This is required for the RCLL/PExC simulation to show robot labels.
values.title: gz3d: enable visuals display

values.description:
Add an example of loading SDFs using the file API:

`firefox examples/view_sdf_from_file.html`

![ambulancefromfile.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/2822974515-ambulancefromfile.gif)

---

Tested that the example works for:

* Models without meshes (e.g. double pendulum...)
* Models with OBJ meshes (e.g. ambulance, walkway_metal_straight, cloverleaf_interchange...)
* Models with DAE meshes (e.g. bowl...)

Doesn't work yet for:

* Models with ogre materials (e.g. cordless_drill)
* Models with STL meshes

--- 

* Refactored code that loads OBJ + MTL out of scene because the scene class is getting too large.
* Updated `gzscene_test` to exercise the OBJ file API
values.title: Load OBJ from files (no HTTP request)

summary.html:
Add an example of loading SDFs using the file API:

firefox examples/view_sdf_from_file.html

Tested that the example works for:

  • Models without meshes (e.g. double pendulum...)
  • Models with OBJ meshes (e.g. ambulance, walkway_metal_straight, cloverleaf_interchange...)
  • Models with DAE meshes (e.g. bowl...)

Doesn't work yet for:

  • Models with ogre materials (e.g. cordless_drill)
  • Models with STL meshes
  • Refactored code that loads OBJ + MTL out of scene because the scene class is getting too large.
  • Updated gzscene_test to exercise the OBJ file API

values.description:
SDF parser has been extended to support parsing world SDF files.

The `view_sdf_from_url` example should also work. Extra resource and `model.sdf` files just need to be specified through the Resource URLs, see example of loading `shapes.world`:

‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/683123572-load_from_world.png)

values.description:
This PR addresses an issue seen in the SDF Viewer side of [https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org) \(it uses `usingFilesUrls` flag\)

Some models' SDF file have more than one references to a mesh. For example, the [X2 model](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/fuel/models/X2) has 4 headlights \(as seen in the model thumbnail\), but when we want to visualize it, it only displays one. This is because we take this customUrl off the array.

If we keep this customUrl in the array, the model can be displayed without issues.

Can you ptal @{557058:6ff86fcb-b7ab-44a5-b8a6-f6d9cae8b6e8} or @{557058:10b01d41-a2e9-4a41-a907-e6e2f03b6cd5} ? Let me know what do you think.

FYI @{557058:095b1e12-74ed-4e20-b44f-2f0745b616e0}

Screenshots:

Models used in these examples:

* [X2](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/fuel/models/X2)
* [Pioneer 3AT](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/fuel/models/Pioneer%203AT)
* [PR2](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/fuel/models/PR2)

Before:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/4027510808-Openrobotics_X2_Before.png)
‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/3644676005-Openrobotics_Pioneer3AT_Before.png)
‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/2005581282-Openrobotics_PR2_Before.png)
‌

After:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/244604871-Openrobotics_X2.png)
‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/2512581287-Openrobotics_Pioneer3AT.png)
‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/3417088016-Openrobotics_PR2.png)
values.title: Don't remove customUrl when using Files Urls

summary.raw:
This PR addresses an issue seen in the SDF Viewer side of [https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org) \(it uses `usingFilesUrls` flag\)

Some models' SDF file have more than one references to a mesh. For example, the [X2 model](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/fuel/models/X2) has 4 headlights \(as seen in the model thumbnail\), but when we want to visualize it, it only displays one. This is because we take this customUrl off the array.

If we keep this customUrl in the array, the model can be displayed without issues.

Can you ptal @{557058:6ff86fcb-b7ab-44a5-b8a6-f6d9cae8b6e8} or @{557058:10b01d41-a2e9-4a41-a907-e6e2f03b6cd5} ? Let me know what do you think.

FYI @{557058:095b1e12-74ed-4e20-b44f-2f0745b616e0}

Screenshots:

Models used in these examples:

* [X2](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/fuel/models/X2)
* [Pioneer 3AT](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/fuel/models/Pioneer%203AT)
* [PR2](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/fuel/models/PR2)

Before:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/4027510808-Openrobotics_X2_Before.png)
‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/r77Gja/images/3644676005-Openrobotics_Pioneer3AT_Before.png)

‌

summary.html:
This PR addresses an issue seen in the SDF Viewer side of https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/ (it uses usingFilesUrls flag)

Some models' SDF file have more than one references to a mesh. For example, the X2 model has 4 headlights (as seen in the model thumbnail), but when we want to visualize it, it only displays one. This is because we take this customUrl off the array.

If we keep this customUrl in the array, the model can be displayed without issues.

Can you ptal @Louise Poubel or @Ian Chen ? Let me know what do you think.

FYI @Nate Koenig

Screenshots:

Models used in these examples:

  • X2
  • Pioneer 3AT
  • PR2

Before:

‌

‌

‌

After:

‌

‌
